title: The Ternary Operator (Shortcut Decision)

syntaxBreakdown.explanation: The three parts: condition to check, value if true (after ?), value if false (after :). The whole expression RETURNS a value!
The parentheses around the condition are optional but make it clearer: (age >= 18) ? ... is more readable than age >= 18 ? ...
The ternary operator PRODUCES a value, so you can assign it: string x = condition ? 'yes' : 'no'; or use it inline: Console.WriteLine(x > 5 ? 'big' : 'small');
You CAN nest ternaries but it gets hard to read fast! grade >= 90 ? 'A' : grade >= 80 ? 'B' : 'C'. Use regular if-else when it's complex!

challenge.instructions:
Create a game status checker using the ternary operator!

1. Create these variables:
   - int health = 75
   - int energy = 30
2. Use ternary operators to create:
   - string healthStatus = (health > 50) ? 'Healthy' : 'Injured'
   - string energyStatus = (energy > 50) ? 'Energized' : 'Tired'
3. Display both statuses

Bonus: Try changing the values to see different results!
challenge.hint: Format: variable = (condition) ? "value if true" : "value if false"; Remember the ? and : symbols!
commonStickingPoints: Forgetting the colon: The : is REQUIRED! condition ? trueValue is incomplete. Must have : falseValue at the end.
Using curly braces: Don't write (age >= 18) ? { 'Adult' } - the values don't use braces, just the value itself!
Mixing types: (age >= 18) ? 'Adult' : 0 is WRONG! Both values must be the same type (both strings, both ints, etc.).
Overusing ternaries: Nested ternaries get VERY hard to read. If you have 3+ levels, use if-else instead for clarity!
